titleStmt.title: Greek verse inscription in honour of Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus praet. prefect from Sidyma

availability.licence: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

summary.term: Honorary inscription for the praetorian prefect Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus
poetry (uncertain: irregular hexametric rhythm; sotadei according to Merkelbach 1978; rhythmic prosa according to Feissel 2011-2012)

layout.p: The text is inscribed on one field for each of the two (square) blocks («auf zwei grossen viereckigen Altären», according to Benndorf who examined them in 1882).

history.provenance: The inscription was found in Sidyma on two large quadrangular blocks or altars, near the access to an aedicula in a garden not far from “the street of tombs”

lg.l:
Τατιανός μετὰ δικανικήν
τρισὶν ἄρχουσιν συνκαθεσθείς

ἡγεμόνι βικαρίῳ ἀνθυπάτῳ
δυσίν τ’ ἐπάρχοις

ἀρχήν Θηβαίων λάχεν, ἔπειτ’
Αἰγύπτου πάσης,

κεῖθεν ὑπατικὸς Συρίης ἠδ’ ὅλης
ἄρχος ἐῴας

θησαυρῶν τε θείων κόμης
εἶτ’ ἔπαρχος μέγας φάνη·

ταῦτα δ’ ἔτι πράττων ἔτεσι
τριάκοντα καὶ τρισίν

δέξατ’ ἀείδιον ὑπάτων στέφανον
εἵνεκα πάντων.

ν ἀφ’ ἑαυτοῦ γνω
λου σπουδῇ τίνος;

οἱ θεῖοι βασιλεῖς τοῖς ἔργοισιν αὐτοῦ
χαίροντες

ὡς ἂν αὐτῷ κῦδος καὶ τιμήν μεγά
λην ὀπάσοιεν

πάντας ἐπ’ ἀνθρώπους ἅμα τ’ αὐτίκα
καὶ μετέπειτα

οὕνεκ’ ἀπειρεσίους πόνους αἷσιν
ἤνυσεν ἀρχαῖς.

div.p: This edition follows the text edited by Merkelbach, Stauber, SGO IV, 2002, nr. 17／8／3, with emendations by Feissel 2011-2012, p. 80.

app.note: ανὸς: CIG; δικανικὴ[ν τοῖς]: CIG; Benndorf-Niemann; Kaibel; Cougny; ILS; TAM; Livrea
ε[ἶτ]: Benndorf-Niemann; Kaibel; Cougny; ILS; TAM; Livrea; λάχεν [ἦδ]: CIG
[καὶ ἔπ]: CIG; ἡδ’ [ἔπ]: Kaibel; Cougny; Livrea; ἡδ’ ὄ[πλ]: Mekelbach
φαν[είς: CIG; Cougny; Livrea; φανί[ς]: Kaibel
ἀειδιων: CIG; ὑπάτων [λάχος]: CIG; Benndorf-Niemann; Kaibel; Cougny; ILS; TAM; Livrea
[ὡς αὐτὸ]ν: TAM; [τὴ]ν: CIG; [ὡς παλι]ν: Benndorf-Niemann; γνω[στὸν με]: TAM; γν[ώμεν]: CIG; γν[ωσθῆ μεγ]: Benndorf-Niemann; Kaibel; Cougny and Livrea don’t read the whole line

Kaibel, Cougny, Livrea 1997 omit both the lines
[ὡς παλι]ν ἀψ’ ἑαυτοῦ γν[ωσθῇ μεγ]|άλου σπουδή τινο[ς ἄθλου]: Benndorf-Niemann; Grégoire
[ὡς αὐτὸ]ν ἀφ’ ἑαυτοῦ γν[ωστὸν με|γ]ά̣λου σπουδῇ τινο[ς]: TAM
ἔρ[γοισι]: CIG; Benndorf-Niemann; Kaibel; Cougny; TAM; Livrea
ὑπατίας: Kaibel; Cougny; τε[ίμησαν]: Kaibel; Livrea 1997; τι[μησαν]: Cougny; στέ[ψαντο]: Benndorf-Niemann
αὐτ[ῷ]: CIG; αὐ[τ]ῷ: Kaibel; Livrea; τ[ερπω]λὴν: CIG; τι[μ]ὴν: Kaibel; Cougny; Livrea
τ[οὺς τότε]: CIG; Kaibel; Cougny; Livrea
πόνους [ἐξ]|ήνυσεν: Benndorf-Niemann; TAM; [ἐξή]νυσεν Kaibel; Cougny; Livrea; [δη]νυσεν: CIG

div.p: “Tatianus, dopo l’attività forense, fu assistente di tre dignitari: di un governatore, di un vicario, di un proconsole e di due prefetti; ottenne il potere sui Tebani, poi su tutto l’Egitto, quindi rifulse consolare di Siria, e responsabile di tutto l’Oriente, indi conte dei tesori imperiali, infine grandioso prefetto: e mentre ancora militava nell’amministrazione nel trentatreesimo anno per tutti questi motivi ricevette la corona dei consoli che dona l’eternità. [...] Per volere di chi giunse così in alto ? Gli imperatori di stirpe divina, compiaciuti dal suo agire, in contraccambio lo coronarono con il consolato che dona l’immortalità, così che congiunsero in lui la gloria con un onore grande davanti a tutti gli uomini, nell’immediato e per sempre, perché egli sopportò innumerevoli fatiche durante i suoi incarichi.”

“Tatianus, after his legal activity, was assistant to three dignitaries: to a governor, a vicar, a proconsul and two prefects; he obtained power over the population of Thebes, then over all Egypt, shone as consularis of Syria and responsible for the whole East, then count of the imperial treasures, and finally great prefect: and while still in administration in the thirty-third year, for all these reasons, he received the crown of consuls that bestows eternity. [...] At the behest of those who reached so high? The emperors of divine lineage, pleased by his actions, in return crowned him with the consulate that gave him immortality, so that they united in him the glory with a great honour before all men, immediately and forever, because he endured innumerable labours during his duties.”

“Tatianus, après son oeuvre d’avocat, fut assistant de trois fonctionnaires: d’un gouverneur, d’un vicaire, d’un proconsul et de deux préfets; il obtint le pouvoir sur les Thébains, puis sur toute l’Egypte, puis brilla consulaire de Syrie, et responsable pour l’Orient entier, puis comte des trésors impériaux, et enfin grand préfet : et alors qu’il était encore en administration la trente-troisième année pour toutes ces raisons reçut la couronne de consuls qui donne l’éternité. [...] Par la volonté de qui est-il arrivé si haut ? Les empereurs de la lignée divine, satisfaits de ses actions, le couronnèrent en retour du consulat qui lui donna l’immortalité, afin qu’ils unissent en lui la gloire avec un grand honneur devant tous les hommes, immédiatement et pour toujours, car il a enduré d’innombrables fatigues pendant ses fonctions.”

The inscription, chiselled on two large quadrangular altars, was set up in honour of the praetorian prefect Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus (PLRE I, pp. 876-878) in the ancient city of Sidyma (Lycia), today known as Dudurga Asari (Turkey). Unfortunately, the exact dimensions of the two stone blocks are unknown. The space in which the inscription was found marked the access to an aedicula in the middle of a valley, in a garden not far from the “the street of the tombs” (Livrea 1997; SGO IV, 2002, nr. 17-8-3).

Our inscription shows three peculiarities: 1) it is engraved on two distinct blocks and not on a single base as one would expect for an inscription bearing the cursus honorum of the praised senator. 2) the name of the prefect and consul Tatianus (in the nominative case) who was tried and sentenced to exile by Theodsius I between 392 and 393 AD, has not been erased, unlike elsewhere (erased in: PPRET 82, 83, 84, 85, 86, 88; the only exception is the memory of hydraulic works in Canopus in Egypt, PPRET 90; about the trial see the critical commentary in PPRET 91). 3) The name (or names) of the dedicator was never inserted, since such an indication was clearly never intended. Here, it would be useful to cite a monument that was put up by the city of Sidyma in honour of the senator, whose family had property there (Theoph., AM 5934; Cedr., 01, 603; Nic. Call., 15, 01; Zon. 13, 24, 06-11).

In this case, the silence of the authorities who raised the monument, inscribed on two ‘twin’ bases would be justified if it were erected in a public space; but Tatianus’ name would certainly have been erased after his condemnation between 392 and 393 AD. It is hard to imagine how such an ostentatious double monument could remain so intact (on the case nominative in honorary inscriptions cf. Mednikarova 2003; Ma 2013, pp. 17-21).

It is highly likely that the blocks decorated the entrance to the senator’s sepulchral building right outside of Sidyma and escaped damage. The insistence on the ordinary consulate for more than half a composition might have been an attempt to cover up the condemnation of the memory of Tatianus whose deeds were annulled by Theodosius I (CTh 09, 42, 12-13; CTh 11, 01, 23; CTh 12, 01, 131). After that sentence, his name in the dating of the year 391 AD remained as evidence of the glorious career of a convicted senator, who would have been rehabilitated only about 55 years later (PPRET 91).

One could cautiously imagine that after 392/393 AD the local civic authorities would not have had the courage to intervene in the inscription in the burial area of Sidyma’s most powerful family. The two stone blocks could have been walled into the facade of the tomb, or they could have supported two statues of the dignitary, one as praetorian prefect and one as ordinary consul.

The metric of the verses, if it is dactylic, it is incorrect (Livrea 1997): the author of the inscription intended to produce hexameters, which, however, was not fully successful (so Kaibel 1878); Grégoire (1922) wrote: «L’auteur [...] a cru faire des hexametres»; Merkelbach (1978) assumed that the verses are sotadei.

The hypothesis that the building where the inscription was located is the burial ground of Tatianus’ family does not convince Livrea. According to the latter, such a wealthy and cultured family would have never allowed a family member to be celebrated by such a bad poet. Recently Feissel (2011-2012, p. 80) suggested that the text is not metric, but rhythmic or poetic prose.

The inscription from Sidyma is the only one to retain the complete cursus honorum of Tatianus. It began in 358 AD, thirty-three years before the ordinary consulate of 391 AD, celebrated in our monument (ll. 11-12).

Tatianus was first a lawyer in the administrative courts, an activity that did not place him at the level of the great nobility; then he was an assistant and legal adviser to two provincial governors, a diocesan vicar and two prefects (ll. 2-4), maybe in 358/363 AD. The late roman dignitaries are listed in increasing order of importance in the ordo dignitatum (praeses, vicar, proconsul, then prefects, perhaps the prefect of Constantinople and the praetorian prefect of the East). Tatianus was praeses Thebaidis perhaps in 364/365 AD (no dated evidence); then praefectus Aegypti in Egypt in 367-370 AD (attested by no less than eight different sources; for discussion on his titulature Olszaniec 2013, pp. 395-397). He was promoted to the joint offices of consularis Syriae and comes Orientis in 370-374 AD, when the emperor Valens was in Antioch with his court, fighting against the Persians (Libanius criticized Tatianus’ brutality for the excessive number of death sentences during his administration, Lib., Or. 46, 08).

Feissel has improved the integration of the office extended to the supervision of the Oriens diocese, as comes Orientis: ὅ[λης] | ἄρχος ἐῴας (ll. 7-8) (it’s compatible with the curved letter visible on the stone: previous proposals, ὅ[πλ]|αρχος ἐῴας and [ἔπ]|αρχος ἐῴας are less satisfactory).

The friendship with Libanius began with this stay in Antioch. The emperors Valens and then Theodosius I gave to Tatianus a long mandate in Constantinople as Comes Sacrarum Largitionum (374-380 AD; cf. Delmaire 1989, pp. 62-67), even in the delicate period that followed the defeat of Hadrianopolis (his office is attested by six constitutions in the law Codes).

After an intense and important career, lasting sixteen years, eight years of otium followed. When the powerful praetorian prefect of the East Maternus Cynegius died, on March 388 AD (PPRET 75), Theodosius I chose Tatianus as his successor. Tatianus was in office from the Spring of 388 to mid 392 AD. Soon, in April 388 AD, Theodosius went to war against the usurper Maximus, defeated him on August 28th in Aquileia and stayed in Italy until July 391 AD, when he returned to Constantinople.

For over three years (338-391 AD) Tatianus remained the highest civil authority in the East. His activity as praetorian prefect is largely testified by thirty-seven constitutions of the law Codes, by at least twenty-eight letters of Libanius, and by other sources, including a series of dedications made by the prefect to the sovereigns (PPRET 82-86), and inscriptions relating to his building interventions (PPRET 88 and 90). In 391 AD his career was crowned by the ordinary consulate (next to Q. Aur. Symmachus, CLRE, pp. 316-317).

The consulate was the most prestigious office of the late Roman cursus honorum and is long celebrated in this inscription (on the late Roman consulate cf. CLRE, pp. 1-89; Sguaitamatti 2012; Petrini 2015). Between June 30th and August 26th 392 AD, Tatianus was suddenly deposed, tried and sentenced to exile in Lycia, his homeland (PPRET 91); his son Proculus was executed in December 393 AD (PPRET 89).

Their names were erased on inscriptions (see above), but not on ours. Tatianus was rehabilitated, but that was more than fifty years later. His grandson at Aphrodisias commemorated him (PPRET 91) and the name of his son Proculus was restored on the base of the obelisk of Theodosius I in Constantinople (PPRET 89); for monuments to rehabilitated praetorian prefects see PPRET 46, 48, 93.

The date of our inscription seems to be the year of the consulate or the following year before the fall of the senator (391/ first half of 392 AD). It cannot be completely excluded that our present inscription is instead the epitaph of Tatianus, engraved after 396 AD, when he seems to have been still alive (CTh 09, 38, 09); for the later restoration of the Greek funeral eulogy for the prefect Maiorinus see PPRET 26; for a prefect’s epitaph with a cursus honorum see PPRET 64.

Praise of the prefect’s hard work as an administrator can be found in the inscriptions honouring Philippus (PPRET 28 and 31). On Tatianus’ career cf. Seeck 1906, pp. 285-288; Ensslin, RE, IVA, 2/1932, coll. 2463-2467 s.v. Tatianus 3; PLRE I, pp. 876-878; Delmaire 1989, pp. 62-67; Petit 1994, pp. 240-243; Olszaniec 2013, pp. 394-407.

div.p: ἀπειρεσίους πόνους αἷσιν ἤνυσεν ἀρχαῖς
ἔπαρχος μέγας
